speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to start by asking you a few questions. Can you tell me more about when you first noticed the episodes of apnea? Was it at birth, or did they start later on?

speaker: Patient
text: I think it started a little while after I was born, but I was in the hospital for a while because I was born early. My mom said I was okay most of the time, but sometimes I would just stop breathing for a little bit.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that the episodes of apnea started shortly after birth. That's helpful information. Can you tell me more about your infant's feeding habits - are they able to feed normally, or do they seem to struggle with latching or feeding in general?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really have trouble latching or anything, but my mom says I get a little tired when I'm eating. Sometimes I'll just stop eating and fall asleep.

speaker: Doctor
text: They seem to struggle a bit with latching, but once they do, they can feed normally. They tend to get tired easily during feedings, though.

speaker: Patient
text: My mom says I've been looking a little pale lately. She says it's nothing to worry about, but I don't know.

speaker: Doctor
text: How often do these episodes of apnea occur, and are there any specific triggers that seem to set them off?

speaker: Patient
text: They happen more often at night, I think. Sometimes my mom says she can hear me making these little sounds, like I'm trying to breathe, but it's really quiet.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any other symptoms in your infant, such as pale or blue-tinged skin, or any changes in their bowel movements?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom says my eyes look a little pale, like I said. And sometimes when I'm sleeping, she says my face gets a bit blue, but she thinks it's just because I'm not breathing for a second.

speaker: Doctor
text: The episodes of apnea seem to be happening fairly frequently, I'd say around 2-3 times a day. Can you tell me if your infant has had any recent vaccinations or exposures to potential allergens?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom says I had a vaccination recently, but I don't know what it was for. I think it was a few weeks ago, when I was still in the hospital.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the frequent episodes of apnea and the struggles with latching during feedings. Can you tell me more about your infant's overall weight and growth since birth? Have they been gaining weight at a normal rate?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been gaining weight, but my mom says I'm a bit smaller than other babies my age. I'm not really sure what that means, but I feel okay, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a physical examination to assess your infant's overall condition. Can you please lift up their shirt so I can take a look at their abdomen?

speaker: Patient
text: My tummy's a little soft, I think. It doesn't feel like it's hard or anything.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken a look at your infant's abdomen, and it appears to be soft and non-tender. However, I do notice that their belly is slightly larger than I would expect for an infant of their age. Can you tell me more about your infant's bowel movements - have they been having more frequent or loose stools than usual?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really have any bowel movements, actually. My mom says I'm not really having any poops, but she's not really worried about it.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the enlarged abdomen. Have you noticed any blood in your infant's stool or urine?

speaker: Patient
text:
No, I don't think so. My mom doesn't say anything about that. 

My mom does say that my eyes look a little funny sometimes. She says they're not really blue, but they're not really white either. 

It seems like I get a bit tired pretty easily, even when I'm not eating. Sometimes I just fall asleep when my mom is holding me.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the enlarged abdomen and the struggles with latching during feedings. Have you noticed any signs of jaundice in your infant, such as a yellowish discoloration of their skin or eyes?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, but my mom says I get a little yellowish sometimes, but she says it's just my skin and it's okay.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request some test results to help me narrow down the possible causes of your infant's symptoms. Can you tell me if you have a copy of the birth weight and the current weight of your infant available?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom says I was really small when I was born, and I'm still a bit smaller than other babies my age. But like I said, I'm not really sure what that means, and my mom seems to think I'm okay.

speaker: Doctor
text: The birth weight was 6 pounds 8 ounces, and the current weight is 8 pounds 2 ounces. That's a good gain, but I'm still concerned about the frequent episodes of apnea and the struggles with latching. Can you tell me more about your family's medical history - have any of your relatives had similar health issues?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom said I have a big sister who's healthy and happy. But my dad has a heart thing, I think. My mom said it's not really the same, but I'm not really sure what that means.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have any of your relatives had a history of cancer, particularly a type of cancer that affects the blood or digestive system?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom doesn't think so, but I'm not really sure. My dad's heart thing, whatever it is, doesn't seem to be the same as what I have.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your family's medical history. Can you tell me more about your own medical history - have you experienced any issues with your blood or digestive system, such as anemia or digestive problems?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I've ever had any problems with my blood or digestive system. I just get a little tired sometimes, and my mom says I have pale eyes.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your family's medical history and your own medical history. Can you tell me if you've noticed any signs of discomfort or pain in your infant's abdomen, such as arching of the back or drawing up of the legs?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, my mom just says I get a little fussy sometimes, but she thinks it's just because I'm hungry or tired.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your infant's family and personal medical history. Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your infant's breathing patterns between episodes of apnea, such as faster or slower breathing?

speaker: Patient
text: Sometimes my breathing sounds really loud when I'm not having an episode, but then it just gets really quiet and I stop breathing for a little bit. It's kind of weird.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your infant's skin color between episodes of apnea, such as pale or blue-tinged skin?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, my mom says my skin gets a bit blue sometimes when I'm not breathing for a second. And sometimes it looks a bit pale, too.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request some test results to help me narrow down the possible causes of your infant's symptoms. Can you tell me if you have a copy of the infant's hemoglobin levels and blood counts available?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know, my mom hasn't shown me any of those papers. But I think I had some blood tests a little while ago when I was in the hospital.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Based on the information you've provided, I've taken note of the frequent episodes of apnea, struggles with latching during feedings, enlarged abdomen, and the family's medical history. I'm concerned that your infant may be experiencing a condition that's related to anemia and digestive issues.

Before I make a final diagnosis, I'd like to confirm one more thing. Have you noticed any signs of failure to thrive in your infant, such as poor weight gain or a lack of interest in feeding despite being hungry?
